title: Warli and Pithora Folk Art - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Warli and Pithora Traditional Painting Styles

questions.question: What is folk art?
options: The art of the people of a specific geographical region
questions.explanation: Folk art is the art of the people of a specific geographical region. The history of folk art and tribal art in India is as old as the history of its people.

questions.question: Who traditionally executes folk and tribal art in India?
questions.explanation: Folk and tribal art drawings and paintings are made with available natural colours on walls and ground, and these are usually executed by women.

questions.question: How is folk art tradition passed down through generations?
options: Girls learn under guidance of older women and pass the skill to next generation
questions.explanation: Girls learn to make folk art under the guidance of older women and in turn, pass the skill and craft on to the next generation of girls, continuing the tradition.

questions.question: What materials are used for making folk art colors?
options: Yellow earth, ochre, chalk, lamp soot, rice powder, turmeric, sindoor, indigo, cow-dung, vegetable colours
questions.explanation: Folk art is made using yellow earth, ochre, chalk, lamp soot, rice powder, turmeric powder, sindoor, indigo, cow-dung and vegetable colours - all natural materials.

questions.question: What is used as a brush in traditional folk art?
questions.explanation: A twig and a rag are turned into a brush for creating folk art, showing the resourcefulness of traditional artists.

questions.question: Where do Warli paintings originate?
questions.explanation: Warli paintings are made by the indigenous Warli community in the Thane district of Maharashtra and are named after its practitioners.

questions.question: What is the speciality of Warli painting?
options: Its simple, natural and ancient form
questions.explanation: The speciality of Warli painting is its simple, natural and ancient form. These paintings are similar to the prehistoric cave paintings found all over the country.

questions.question: How are human and animal forms created in Warli painting?
options: By joining two triangles at the apex
questions.explanation: Human and animal forms in Warli painting are created by joining two triangles at the apex, creating unadorned, undetailed yet brilliantly dynamic and harmonious figures.

questions.question: What do Warli paintings generally represent?
options: The environs and life of the Warli people
questions.explanation: The paintings generally represent the environs and life of the Warli people, documenting their daily activities and environment.

questions.question: Where are Warli paintings traditionally done?
questions.explanation: Warli painting is traditionally done on walls. However, for the urban market, Warli painting is nowadays executed on paper and fabric as well.

questions.question: Who is Palghat Devi in Warli tradition?
questions.explanation: Palghat Devi is the Warli goddess of fertility. A figure of Palghat Devi is painted in the center of the large rectangle called Chauk for wedding rituals.

questions.question: What is a Chauk in Warli painting?
options: A large rectangle where the fertility goddess is painted
questions.explanation: Chauk is a large rectangle in which the figure of Palghat Devi, the fertility goddess, is painted in the center for wedding-related rituals.

questions.question: What is painted on the top two corners of the Chauk?
options: Representational figures of the sun and moon or Basing (ceremonial crown)
questions.explanation: On the top two corners of the Chauk, representational figures of the sun and the moon or Basing, the ceremonial crown worn by the bride and groom are painted.

questions.question: What scenes surround the Chauk in Warli wedding paintings?
options: Wedding scenes and everyday activities including bridegroom on mare, dancing, hunting, farming
questions.explanation: The chowk is surrounded by wedding scenes and everyday activities including the bridegroom riding a mare, men and women dancing, hunting and farming scenes, drawing of toddy, flora and fauna.

questions.question: Who executes the Warli Chowk painting?
questions.explanation: Married women invariably execute the Chowk, but after that, enthusiastic younger women cover the wall with scenes from life.

questions.question: How do Warli people construct their houses?
options: By erecting a bamboo structure and filling gaps with mud
questions.explanation: Warli people build their houses by erecting a bamboo structure and then filling the gaps with mud.

questions.question: What is used to plaster Warli house walls?
options: Cow dung and red earth slurry
questions.explanation: The walls thus constructed are plastered with cow dung and red earth slurry before being decorated with paintings.

questions.question: What material is used for making Warli paintings on walls?
questions.explanation: The walls are decorated with paintings, traditionally by married women, made with a rice flour paste, creating white paintings on a reddish-brown background.

questions.question: How is a brush made for Warli painting?
options: One end of salati grass stem or palm leaf rib is beaten into a fibrous mass
questions.explanation: One end of the stem of the local salati grass or the rib of the palm leaf is beaten into a fibrous mass and turned into a brush.

questions.question: What creates the aesthetic of Warli paintings?
options: White paintings on a reddish-brown background
questions.explanation: The white paintings on a reddish-brown background have a rare elegance, which is the distinctive aesthetic of Warli art.

questions.question: Who is Kansari Ai in Warli tradition?
questions.explanation: Kansari Ai is the tribal deity of crops. Warli farmers first ritually offer freshly harvested paddy to Kansari Ai.

questions.question: What is Pashti painting in Warli tradition?
options: Figures painted by repeating paisley-like impressions of the fisted hand
questions.explanation: For offerings to Kansari Ai, Pashti designed figures are painted on the outer wall of the house and mud storage containers by repeating paisley-like impressions of the fisted hand.

questions.question: Who is the artist of the famous Warli work 'Palghat Devi Chauk'?
questions.explanation: The famous Warli work 'Palghat Devi Chauk' was created by artist Jeevya Soma Mashe and is in the collection of Crafts Museum, New Delhi.

questions.question: Which communities practice Pithora painting?
options: Bheel and Bhilala of Madhya Pradesh and Rathwas of Gujarat
questions.explanation: The Bheel and Bhilala communities of Jhabua district of Madhya Pradesh and the Rathwas of the Vadodra area of Gujarat have a long, rich tradition of Pithora painting.

questions.question: Why are these paintings called Pithora paintings?
options: Because they are executed to appease the local deity Pithora
questions.explanation: Since these paintings are executed to appease the local deity Pithora, they are known as Pithora paintings.

questions.question: What is the difference between Bheel and Rathwa Pithora painting palettes?
options: Bheel palette is simple and limited; Rathwa palette has vivid colours and more detail
Rathwa uses only black and white
questions.explanation: The Bheel palette is comparatively simple, limited and old, while the Rathwa palette is marked by its vivid colours. The Rathwa Pithora painting also has more detail and ornamentation.

questions.question: When do Bheel and Rathwa communities commission Pithora paintings?
options: When their wish for a good crop or a son is fulfilled
questions.explanation: Members of the Bheel and Rathwa communities traditionally appeal to deity Pithora to grant them a good crop or a son. When their wish is fulfilled, they commission a Lakhindra to make these paintings.

questions.question: Who is a Lakhindra?
options: A traditional painter of sacred frescoes
questions.explanation: A Lakhindra is a traditional painter of sacred frescoes who is commissioned to make Pithora paintings in connection with rituals.

questions.question: What are modern Pithoras painted on for urban buyers?
options: Paper or fabric with acrylic colours
questions.explanation: Nowadays, many Bheel and Rathwa artists are making decorative and exotic Pithoras for the urban buyer on paper or fabric with acrylic colours.

questions.question: Where is the traditional Pithora painting made?
options: On the main inner wall of the house
questions.explanation: The traditional Pithora painting is painted on the main inner wall of the house.

questions.question: How is the wall prepared for Pithora painting?
options: Plastered with cow dung and mud slurry, then painted with lime or white earth
questions.explanation: The wall is first plastered with cow dung and mud slurry and then painted with lime or white earth before painting begins.

questions.question: What is called 'Pithora's house' in the painting?
options: A rectangular space created by painting an outline in white
questions.explanation: A rectangular space called 'Pithora's house' is created by painting an outline in white on the prepared wall.

questions.question: What do the two horses in the upper middle portion of Pithora painting represent?
questions.explanation: The two horses in the upper middle portion represent the deity Pithora; other horses represent other deities.

questions.question: Which figures must be included in a complete Pithora painting?
options: Two-headed mares, lion, elephant, camel, cow, rabbit, cobra, scorpion, cat, peacock, fish, hen, step-well, and many more specific figures
questions.explanation: A complete Pithora must include specific figures like two-headed mares, lion, elephant, camel, cow, rabbit, cobra, scorpion, cat, peacock, fish, hen, step-well, woman drawing water, water carrier, women whisking curds, one-legged man smoking hookah, twelve-headed demons, man with baskets, monkeys, caged parrot, palm tree, beehive, sun, moon, farmer with plough and bullocks, couple in coitus, and the black rider Kathia Sawar.

questions.question: What happens if even one companion of Pithora is missing from the painting?
options: The painting would be considered incomplete
questions.explanation: Without even one of these companions of Pithora, the painting would be considered incomplete. They all occur again and again in the ritual Pithora songs.

questions.question: What material is used to make the brush for Pithora painting?
options: A twig of a date tree beaten till it turns fibrous
questions.explanation: The material for Pithora painting brush is a twig of a date tree. It is cut, and one end is beaten with a hammer or stone till it turns into a fibrous mass.

questions.question: What colors are traditionally used in Pithora paintings?
options: White (lime paste), pink (diluted Mahavar), brown (ochre), yellow (Pewri), green (Balor leaves), black (lamp soot), blue (laundry blue/indigo)
questions.explanation: Traditional Pithora painting uses white colour (lime paste), vibrant pink colour (diluted Mahavar), brown colour (ochre), yellow colour (made with Pewri), green colour (made with Balor leaves), black colour (made with lamp soot), blue colour (made with laundry blue or indigo).

questions.question: What is the purpose of folk and tribal art in India?
options: Carried out for public or personal good and part of particular rituals as well as non-rituals
questions.explanation: In its traditional form, folk and tribal art in India is an activity of a particular geographical region or community carried out for public or personal good and is part of particular rituals as well as non-rituals.

questions.question: What is Basing in Warli wedding paintings?
options: The ceremonial crown worn by the bride and the groom
questions.explanation: Basing is the ceremonial crown worn by the bride and the groom, which may be painted in the top corners of the Chauk along with or instead of the sun and moon.

questions.question: When are different folk art designs made throughout the year?
questions.explanation: Folk art paintings are made around the year, with different designs/motifs/compositions for different occasions, showing the integration of art with daily and ritual life.
